oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Men, women and children wait in the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) out-patient clinic. Six nurses in the room attend to the patients. One boy is weighed by a nurse. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Report of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) for October-December 1927; Dr. Philip Hillkowitz was the Society's President. The issue is an obituary and tribute for C.D. Spivak, 1861-1927. Includes biographical information, writings about his early life, an article about his final days, and essays about his contributions: to the JCRS, to medicine, as a social worker, as a humanitarian, as a Zionist, and as a paragon of virtue. Also includes information about memorial meetings, comments from the English, Yiddish, and Hebrew press, two letters written by Dr. Spivak, writings published posthumously, and a bibliography of his works. Six portraits of Dr. Spivak at various points in his life are in this report. Contributors to the issue are Dr. Victor Yarros, Dr. Philip Hillkowitz, Dr. Boris D. Bogen, Dr. Herman Schwatt, Dr. M. Sahud, Rabbi C. E. Hillel Kauvar, Max Shulman, Isaac Rivkind, and Henry Rosen.

Includes transcripts of speakers' addresses at the cornerstone laying for the sanatorium's Texas Pavilion for Women, text of Dr. Allen K. Also includes photographs of Philip Hillkowitz, Mrs. L. B. Rosenburg, Rabbi Morris Taxon, Harry Sigel, Hon. Maurice Hirsch, the Texas Pavilion for Women, and the "cow hotel" barn. The editorial announces the death of C. D. Spivak and notes that the next issue will be a tribute.

Samuel Krone salts meat at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Rev. Krone was the Mashgiach (kosher supervisor) for over 18 years at the JCRS. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Messing, Joseph,--1886-1925
Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (U.S.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joseph Messing sits on a small table at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). He is wearing a cable-knit shawl collar sweater over his shirt and tie. Originally from Poland, he immigrated to the United States on November 5, 1905. Joseph Messing worked in New York City as a cutter, contracted tuberculosis there, and was a patient at the JCRS from December 24, 1923 to February 19, 1924, and from March 30 to June 24, 1925. He died November 27, 1925 in Queens, New York, survived by four children and his wife Mollie. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Report of the Society for January-July 1928; Dr. Philip Hillkowitz was the Society's President. Includes announcements of Henry Rosen's election as JCRS executive director and Dr. Herman Schwatt's appointment to medical head of the sanatorium, an essay about an outsider's visit to the sanatorium, patients' eulogies at Dr. C. D. Spivak's memorial service, a reprint of the Rocky Mountain News editorial about the Dr. Spivak memorial issue, and correspondence. Also includes photographs of the sanatorium's Texas Pavilion for Women, wards, sunbathing patients, medical equipment, research areas, and flower gardens, plus the first official photograph of the St. Louis JCRS Junior Auxiliary. Additionally, there are portraits of Henry Rosen, Herman Schwatt, and S. Litchy.

Seven men stand around a bed at the dedication of the Yehoash Auxiliary Bed sponsored by the Waterbury, Connecticut Women's Auxiliary. Many of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society's (JCRS) beds were sponsored by charitable contributions, including a number from JCRS women's auxiliaries located around the country. Pictured from left to right are Dr. Herman Schwatt, then the JCRS medical director; Abraham Judelovitz, a Denver builder and JCRS volunteer; Dr. Philip Hillkowitz, longtime president of the JCRS; Ben Frumess; Yehoash (the Yiddish poet Solomon Bloomgarden); Mr. Kulp; and Dr. Charles Spivak.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On back of photograph: "Laying the cornerstone of the round red brick building for less contagious TB patients. Funds from the Ladies Auxiliary of New York, 1908."

A group of people attend a ceremony for the laying of a cornerstone at the New York Ladies Auxiliary building at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) on April 19, 1908. The building was a round, red brick building that housed the less contagious tuberculosis (TB) patients. Rabbi C. E. Kauvar, in a top hat, stands on one side of the cornerstone and Abraham Judelovitz, in coveralls, stands on the other side of the cornerstone. Dr. Philip Hillkowitz with no hat, stands to Rabbi Kauvar's right. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanitorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Tucker Tents, at the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society Sanatarium, Denver, Colo."--On front of photograph at bottom left.

A medical services tent at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) Sanatorium near Edgewater, just west of Denver, Colorado, was dedicated on March 26, 1905. A sign on the door reads: "Laboratory and Dispensary." The sign over the door reads: "Minsker Independent Benevolent Ass'n. New York City." The sign to the right of the door reads: 'This tent erected and furnished by the Minsker Independent Benevolent Association of New York." Early patients and staff were housed in Tucker Tents, which were shelters that helped contain the highly contagious tuberculosis while allowing air to pass through at all times. A boardwalk in the foreground (with doormat) connects this tent to others in the complex. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

A group of people in front of the enlarged 1911 water tower at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Also visible are the stacks of the power plant, and the west side of the central medical building. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A costume party at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) held for patients. Parties were often given for patients of the JCRS as a form of recreation while they recovered from tuberculosis. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Report from the Society for July-September 1919 ; Dr. Philip Hillkowitz was the Society's President, and C.D. Spivak the Secretary. Includes an essay about procedures for patients' admission and discharge, a description of the sanatorium's grounds and buildings written by Robert Willison and C. D. Spivak, and correspondence. Also includes a photograph of the Beth Jacob Synagogue; the J.C.R.S. Poultry-Farm. The description of the grounds includes brief articles on the I. Rude Medical Building, First New York Ladies' Auxiliary Pavilion, Second New York Ladies' Auxiliary Pavilion, Isidor Hurwitz Library and Bookbindery, the Solarium, Administration Building, and the Nurses Home, etc.
